text:
That’s Lindsey.
That’s when she was little.

Every year, she had to have
a red, white, blue cake.

I used to say she’s
my little firecracker.

It’s hard to sleep
sometimes, and I always

think why am I not
dreaming about her?

She just was a
little performer.

I mean, she wouldn’t start
till everybody
was quiet and looking at her.

I thought she was going
to be a strong woman,
and I loved that.

She seemed really
confident, but she seemed

to develop a
low self-esteem.

One of her best friends
was with her boyfriend.

She never seemed
to get over that.
Here’s Lindsey and Cody.
They were so young.

That’s the day
she was born.

I was in there with
Lindsey when she had her.

They were just thrilled
to have a baby.
She worked with older people.

That’s what she wanted
to do, was go be a nurse.

Cody got his job
on the oil rig,

and they seemed really happy,
and she was such a good mom
to Lilah.

She hurt her back
with her job,

and her life kind of
fell apart after that.

She was put on
pain meds, and then she
became addicted to heroin.

I would have done
anything to try
to fix it or take it away.

I eventually took
Lilah from her.
She didn’t fight me on it.

She knew that, that was
what was best for Lilah.

People will say, do you
feel like she’s with you?
And I don’t.
I feel like she’s just gone.

I try to think back to
how I was as a parent.
I think, what did I do wrong?

There was times that I was
really, really hard on her,

and I know that it was before
I really understood it,

but I still hate that I made
her feel worse about herself.

I’ll never forget
Lilah’s face.

Cody told her, he said,
“When you were in Iowa,

your mom got sick,
and she died.”

She just cried, and she
looked at us, and she said,
”But I want her.”
She hasn’t cried since.

She’s just so happy
and confident.

I love that she got all
that from her mother,

but I see so much of Lindsey
in her, and I’m like, O.K.,

I’ve got to do things a
little different with her.

If I say no to
something, she’ll

try to talk me out of it,
and Lindsey was the same way.
She’s 7.
It’s hard.

I mean, when I have her
for four or five days at a time,
I’m worn out.

And I’m going to have to see
her go through so many things

that kids have to go through, I
mean, getting her heart broken,
it’s just so much pain.

One day, she just said,
“My mom was so young,
why did she die?”

I wonder what that’s
going to do to her.
I want to be a good parent.

I want to be how
Lindsey would have been,
how I wanted her to be
to Lilah.

I don’t want to excuse
certain behavior

because I feel sorry
for her, because she
doesn’t have a mother.

Isn’t that cute,
that Lilah will see
how much her mom loved her?

She’d always say, “I hope
I’m half the mother to Lilah

that you are to me,” and
I know she wanted that.
